messages.content:
Can you work as a professional assisstant and take these meeting notes and come up with a cleaned version with lists of questions, action plans and other structued note system elements to help make this meeting jumbled notes doc useful?
No Code Course Hangout
30 more mins.
Objectives: 
Meta Question: 
Can we productize this in any way.
Muj:
N8N
Zapier
Flutterflow
Airtable
Softr
Bubble.
Show and tell, airtable / show and tell. 
Instead of show and tell we did a show and build
Together we build a little app to order food for an event and brought a menu for one of the restaurants and got the options 
Can we give the homework and not let them in to the second part if they don‚Äôt. 

Muj Objective
What to do in the  meeting tomorrow?
Is Munir joining in person?
Should Muj come to the meeting tomorrow?
Can we get their emails?
Can we give the homework and not let them in to the second part if they don‚Äôt. 
Can we record? Who owns the recordings / content?
Have they been working together for a while?
Can we send them prep work to do?
Go find your ‚Äúfavorite‚Äù no-code tool
Share with people?
Download microsoft edge
How to use chatGPT to find their problem and define their question / portfolio.
For the four hours we have together, do they prefer presentation conversation breakouts -> i like hands on and collaborative. 
Muj: Last time I did no code:
We have known about flutter flow / airtable for a while. We haven‚Äôt, we wanted someone to get us started. 
Nice to have someone walk us through first. 


What the hell are we doing with these people?

Preparing some questions/info gathering. 
Remaining questions? 
How long have they been working together?

How do we that that?
WHAT IF IT WAS EASY AND FUN.
(No prep, listen/show them how to figure it out.)
Generic Design From Muj
How are you
Why are you here?
Take all these things and design the session on the fly to cover. 
After we do it. We add two more hours personally where Muj+Bilal 
Checkin:
Bilal:
Checkin, doing one thing at a time. 
Muj:
Back home, feeling like it‚Äôs actually home. Wondering about the experiment and how it‚Äôs going. 
This bowl is awesome, I used to eat my breakfast in this every day. It‚Äôs not about the bowl. Memories stay in the place. Bilal: Is that true? Becoming the memory?

Workshop Information:
Workshop 5 : Software Prototyping tools and methods
At least one person per team is required to attend the program (ideally two )
Participants are required to bring a laptop to all the sessions, this is to facilitate the use of exercises and learning tools
Location :  A6 building ground floor, Al Warsha
Time : 5:00PM - 7:00PM (UAE Time)

‚Äá1.‚Å† ‚Å†Ages: All early twenties, most are current university students at NYUAD, some are recent graduates. 
‚Äá2.‚Å† ‚Å†Scholastic background: Column M in the "Final Cohort" sheet here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1xDTqSg9SH05up8agIQidL1ZGTcFUJvOoyeLciBRJQl8/edit#gid=166574669 
‚Äá3.‚Å† ‚Å†Familiarity with digital tools: Ya, basic ones like Google Docs is fine ... they're all bright tech-savvy university students with basic tools. 
‚Äá4.‚Å† ‚Å†Mac/Windows/Linux: Probably even split Mac/Windows ... I doubt any using Linux. Some teams do have developer members/cofounders though, but not all. 
‚Äá5.‚Å† ‚Å†Laptop vs. Phone: All have both 
‚Äá6.‚Å† ‚Å†Automation tools: For most it will be new. We can add that to a google form though if you want. All are aiming to be digital platforms ... though a fair number connect to offline services (tutoring, supporting local shops and small businesses, connecting people to local workshops / activities, etc) 
‚Äá7.‚Å† ‚Å†Projects: They all have clear projects, idea-stage doing early validation ... see basic info in Columns P & Q in that same g-link I shared above. 
‚Äá8.‚Å† ‚Å†Signing up or Mandatory: It's an optional pre-accelerator program at NYUAD... not for credit, not part of a class. 
9.‚Å† ‚Å†Sending pre-content / pre-readings / pre-videos: 
Yes it's possible. 
There's also a group slack for the group, maybe we can invite you to join that as well (I should probably engage more there ... and it would be great to boost engagement with them ... though it has been a bit of a hectic time. :-/ ) 
10.‚Å† ‚Å†Emails/Social:
Ya sure ... they're trying to do more comms on slack, but we could ask for their socials/etc as well. 

I also started creating this sheet to have compiled shared notes and a sort of "leaderboard" ... but it isn't done yet. Will work on that in the coming days. 
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1s63fERR_deCl8ZUQ_6CoyIGinPWDZj7nKGydkUp3dgc/edit#gid=0

Thoughts? 

Cheers! üôÇ

Based on the meeting notes provided, I've structured them into a cleaner format with distinct sections for questions, action plans, and other relevant elements. This should help in organizing and understanding the key points and tasks from the meeting.

### Meeting Title: No Code Course Hangout

**Date & Duration:** [Date not provided], 30 more mins.

#### Objectives:
- Discuss the potential of productizing the course.

#### Tools Discussed:
- N8N, Zapier, Flutterflow, Airtable, Softr, Bubble.

#### Activities:
- Replaced "show and tell" with "show and build."
- Built a small app to order food for an event.

#### Muj's Questions & Action Items:
1. **Objective for Next Meeting:**
   - Determine the agenda and participants for the next meeting.
   - Decide if Muj and Munir will attend in person.
   - Explore the possibility of recording the session and ownership of recordings/content.
   - Confirm if participants have been collaborating prior to the course.
   - Assign preparatory work: Find a favorite no-code tool, download Microsoft Edge, learn how to use ChatGPT for problem-solving.

2. **Homework Policy:**
   - Consider enforcing homework completion for participation in the second part of the session.

3. **Participant Engagement:**
   - Gather participant emails and social media for communication.
   - Discuss the format preference for the four-hour session (presentation, conversation, breakouts, hands-on, collaborative).

4. **Workshop Preparation:**
   - Prepare questions for gathering information.
   - Design the session spontaneously based on participant responses and needs.
   - Plan a follow-up session with Muj and Bilal for an additional two hours.

#### Personal Check-In:
- Bilal: Focusing on doing one task at a time.
- Muj: Feeling at home, reflecting on past experiences and the ongoing experiment.

#### Workshop Information:
- **Title:** Workshop 5 - Software Prototyping Tools and Methods
- **Requirement:** At least one person per team must attend (ideally two).
- **Participants:** Bring a laptop for exercises and tools.
- **Location & Time:** A6 building ground floor, Al Warsha, 5:00PM - 7:00PM (UAE Time).

#### Participant Demographics:
1. Ages: Early twenties, mostly NYUAD students or recent graduates.
2. Scholastic Background: Refer to "Final Cohort" sheet.
3. Familiarity with Digital Tools: Basic (e.g., Google Docs).
4. Operating Systems: Even split between Mac/Windows.
5. Devices: All have laptops and phones.
6. Automation Tools: New to most participants.
7. Projects: Early-stage validation projects.
8. Program Nature: Optional pre-accelerator at NYUAD.
9. Pre-Content: Sending pre-readings/videos is possible.
10. Communication: Group Slack, emails, and social media.

#### Additional Notes:
- Creation of a shared notes sheet and a "leaderboard" is in progress.

#### Remaining Questions:
- How long have the participants been working together?
- Strategies for making the session easy and fun.

#### Follow-up:
- Engagement on Slack and boosting group interaction.
- Completion of the shared notes sheet and leaderboard.

#### Thoughts and Feedback:
- [Open for input]

#### Closing Remarks:
- Cheers! üôÇ

This structured format should make it easier to address each aspect of the meeting and track progress on action items.

can you write me a quick email to mariam@softr.io telling them that i have this workshop coming up and will be training a bunch of new entrepreneurs at a university in the UAE and would like to know if they have any discount codes they can offer. And that I'd like a professional account at bg@bilalghalib.com to be able to show them more features if possible 
make it short, compelling and don't write too long. Keep simple language and fewer adjectivres

Subject: Inquiry About Discount Codes and Professional Account for Upcoming Workshop

Dear Mariam,

I hope this email finds you well. I'm writing to you regarding an upcoming workshop I am conducting for a group of budding entrepreneurs at a university in the UAE. As part of the training, I plan to introduce them to Softr and its capabilities.

Considering the potential for new users from this workshop, I was wondering if Softr might offer any discount codes for these participants. Such an incentive could significantly encourage their engagement with your platform.

Additionally, I'm interested in accessing a professional account at bg@bilalghalib.com. This would enable me to showcase more advanced features of Softr to the attendees, further enhancing the learning experience.

I look forward to your response and any possibilities for collaboration.

Best regards,

[Your Name]
